2335 The one is spiritual, the other physical.

2469 1 See chapter on “Increasing the Vocabulary.” 1Money.
2470 There are three fundamental requisites for a good voice: 1.
2471 Try this for yourself.
2472 Ease must be your watchword.
2473 Don’t make your voice go—let it go.
2474 But how can I relax?
2475 By simply willing to relax.
2476 Hold your arm out straight from your shoulder.
2477 Now—withdraw all power and let it fall.
2478 For flexibility of lips repeat the syllables, mo—me.
2479 Try the following exercise in the same manner: Mo—E—O—E—OO—Ah.
2480 This is the natural and correct method of breathing.
2481 The next fundamental requisite for good voice is 2.
2482 If so, a skilled physician should be consulted.
2483 The final fundamental requisite for good voice is 3.
2484 You will recall that our first principle was ease.
2485 Think the tone forward and out.
2486 Close the lips, humming ng, im, or an.
2487 Think the tone forward.
2488 Do you feel it strike the lips?
2489 Can you feel the forward tones strike against your hand?
2490 Practise until you can.
2491 It is necessary only to speak correctly.
2492 Do not gaze at the floor as you talk.
2493 Voice is a series of air vibrations.
2494 Breath is the very basis of voice.
2495 Practise this until it becomes second nature.
2496 Take a deep breath.
2497 Get the air into your lungs—that is the important thing.
2498 You can increase its vibrations by practise.
2499 Do you feel the lips vibrate?
2500 Repeat this exercise, throwing the humming sound into the nose.
2501 Can you feel the nose vibrate?
2502 Think the voice there as you hum in head tones.
2503 Can you feel the vibration there?
2504 Then try it on the chest.
2505 What ho, my jovial mates.
2506 Utilize all that you give out.
2507 Failure to do this results in a breathy tone.
2508 Voice Suggestions Never attempt to force your voice when hoarse.
2509 Do not drink cold water when speaking.
2510 Avoid pitching your voice too high—it will make it raspy.
2511 This is a common fault.
2512 Practise it in your daily conversation.

2847 Over-ornamentation makes the subject ridiculous.
2848 Exposition elucidates ideas, description treats of things.
2849 Exposition deals with the abstract, description with the concrete.
2850 Exposition is concerned with the internal, description with the external.
2851 Exposition is enumerative, description literary.
2852 Exposition is intellectual, description sensory.
2853 Exposition is impersonal, description personal.
2854 Rhetoricians make still further distinctions.

2856 Description may be by simple hint.
2857 Description may be direct.
2858 This statement is plain enough without exposition.

2861 Away it soars!
2862 All around at one stroke!

2878 STEVENSON, A Gossip on Romance.
2879 FROM “MIDNIGHT IN LONDON” Clang!
2880 Rattle, clash and clatter.
2881 Open fly the doors; brave men mount their boxes.
2882 The horses tear down the street like mad.
2883 goes the gong!
2884 “Get out of the track!
2885 The engines are coming!
2886 Away dash the horses on the wings of fevered fury.
2887 The sky is ablaze.
2888 A tenement house is burning.
2889 Five hundred souls are in peril.
2890 Spare the victims!
2891 Are the engines coming?
2892 Yes, here they are, dashing down the street.
2893 How the horses dash around the corner!
2894 Animal instinct, say you?
2895 The man’s arm strikes a bystander as he darts down.
2896 The faint-hearted lookers-on hide their faces.
2897 One woman swoons away.
2898 “Aye, Joe, and I knew him well, too!
2899 He lived next door to me, five flights back.
2900 I helped him bury his wife a fortnight ago.
2901 The ladders, there!
2902 “Too short!” he cries.
2903 “Hoist another!” Up it goes.
2904 “Bravo, fireman!” shouts the crowd.
2905 A crash breaks through the uproar of crackling timbers.
2906 “Look alive, up there!
2907 The spectators cease to breathe.
2908 The cold truth reveals itself.
2909 The fireman has been carried into the seething furnace.
2910 He was all I had!
2911 And a brave lad he was, too!
2912 But he’s gone now.
2913 The engines do their work.
2914 The flames die out.
2915 And the noon of night is passed.
2916 QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS 1.
2917 Deliver a short original address in the over-ornamented style.

3028 Is he morally credible?
3029 Is he in a position to know the facts?
3030 Is he an eye-witness?

3032 Is his testimony contradicted?
3033 Is his testimony corroborated?
3034 Is his testimony contrary to well-known facts or general principles?
3035 Is it probable?
3036 What constitutes him an authority?
3037 Is his interest in the case an impartial one?
3038 Does he state his opinion positively and clearly?
3039 Are the non-personal authorities cited (books, etc.) reliable and unprejudiced?
3040 Are they weighty enough in character?
3041 Are they in harmony with reason?
3042 Are they mutually harmonious or contradictory?
3043 Are they admitted, doubted, or disputed?
3044 The principles adduced as evidence Are they axiomatic?
3045 Are they truths of general experience?
3046 Are they truths of special experience?
3047 Are they truths arrived at by experiment?
3048 Were such experiments special or general?
3049 Were the experiments authoritative and conclusive?

3173 ANTONY’S ORATION OVER CÆSAR’S BODY Friends, Romans, countrymen!
3174 The Noble Brutus Hath told you Cæsar was ambitious.
3175 Was this ambition?
3176 Methinks there is much reason in his sayings.
3177 Has he, masters?
3178 I fear there will a worse come in his place.

3180 If it be found so, some will dear abide it.
3181 Poor soul, his eyes are red as fire with weeping.

4628 Proactive: Acts with little or no consideration.
4629 Motivated by doing.
4630 Reactive: Motivated to wait, analyze, consider and react.
4631 They incite a positive physical and emotional reaction.
4632 Toward: They are motivated to achieve or attain goals.
4633 They may have trouble recognizing problems.
4634 They are good at managing priorities.
4635 Internal: They decide based on their own internal standards.
4636 They are motivated by impact, feedback and results.
4637 They may have difficulty following set procedures.
4638 Sameness: They are motivated when things stay the same.
4639 They will provoke change about every 15 to 25 years.
4640 They want major change every 5 to 7 years.
4641 Difference: They want change to be constant and drastic.
4642 Major change every 1 to 2 years.
4643 Major change averages every 3 years.
4644 Specific: Details and sequences.
4645 They tend not to see the overview.
4646 General: Overview, big picture.
4647 Can handle details for short periods.
4648 Self: Attends to own experience.
4649 Doesn't notice others' behavior or voice tone.
4650 Other: Has Automatic reflex responses to nonverbal behavior.
4651 Feeling: Emotional responses to normal levels of stress.
4652 Stays in feelings.
4653 Not suited for high-stress work.
4654 Choice: Can move in and out of feelings voluntarily.
4655 Good at empathy.
4656 Less apt to establish rapport or show empathy.
4657 Independent: Alone with sole responsibility.
4658 Proximity: In control of own territory with others around.
4659 Cooperative: Together with others in a team, sharing responsibility.
4660 Person: Centered on people, relationships, feelings experiences and thoughts.
4661 They become the task.

5261 In some cases they might not even be dead.
5262 Winston stroked his nose gently with a paper-clip.
5263 It was perfectly possible.
5264 Winston did not know why Withers had been disgraced.
5265 Perhaps it was for corruption or incompetence.
5266 Withers, however, was already an UNPERSON.
5267 He did not exist: he had never existed.
5268 What was needed was a piece of pure fantasy.
5269 Today he should commemorate Comrade Ogilvy.

5272 The room was already very full and deafeningly noisy.

5274 Perhaps 'friend' was not exactly the right word.
5275 Syme was a philologist, a specialist in Newspeak.

5277 There had been a famine of them for months past.

5280 'I was working,' said Winston indifferently.

5287 'I'm on the adjectives.
5288 'The Eleventh Edition is the definitive edition,' he said.
5289 But not a bit of it!
5290 We're destroying words—scores of them, hundreds of them, every day.
5291 We're cutting the language down to the bone.
5292 'It's a beautiful thing, the destruction of words.
5293 It isn't only the synonyms; there are also the antonyms.
5294 A word contains its opposite in itself.
5295 Take 'good', for instance.
5296 Of course we use those forms already.

5306 'By 2050—earlier, probably—all real knowledge of Oldspeak will have disappeared.

5308 Even the literature of the Party will change.

5311 Orthodoxy means not thinking—not needing to think.

5316 It is written in his face.

5319 There was something subtly wrong with Syme.

5322 Syme's fate was not difficult to foresee.
5323 Zeal was not enough.
5324 Orthodoxy was unconsciousness.

6429 Winston's heart sank.

6455 Whatever the Party holds to be the truth, is truth.

7705 Sammy rips apart the school grounds looking.
